Cricket is played in three main formats, each with unique characteristics and appeal.

Test Cricket (5 Days):
• Duration: Up to 5 days, 6 hours per day
• Overs: Unlimited (90 overs minimum per day)
• Innings: Each team bats twice
• Clothing: Traditional whites
• Ball: Red leather ball
• Features: Ultimate test of skill, endurance, and strategy

One Day Internationals - ODI (1 Day):
• Duration: 1 day, approximately 8 hours
• Overs: 50 overs per team
• Innings: Each team bats once
• Clothing: Colored uniforms
• Ball: White leather ball
• Features: Balance of skill and entertainment

Twenty20 - T20 (3 Hours):
• Duration: 3 hours approximately
• Overs: 20 overs per team
• Innings: Each team bats once
• Clothing: Colored uniforms
• Ball: White leather ball
• Features: Fast-paced, high entertainment

Additional Formats:
• The Hundred: 100 balls per team
• T10: 10 overs per team
• First-Class: Multi-day domestic cricket
• List A: One-day domestic cricket

Key Differences:
• Strategy varies significantly between formats
• Player roles adapt to format requirements
• Scoring rates increase in shorter formats
• Field restrictions vary by format
